intro.p: You're back in the tutoring center, and intermediate-algebra student {{stu}} brings in a study worksheet for an upcoming exam on quadratic equations.
"I'm stuck on this problem," {{pn}} tell{{suf}} you. "I solved it with factoring, but the online homework system isn't taking my answers." Fortunately, this time {{stu}} has shown {{pos}} work:
"I don't understand what I did wrong," {{stu}} tells you.

content.p: Critique {{stu}}'s solution by describing both something {{pn}} did correctly, and the fundamental error {{pn}} made that resulted in an incorrect answer.

outtro.p: The factoring was a good idea. But, making the right-hand side zero before factoring was what {{stu}} neglected to do.

content.p: Write out a correct step-by-step solution that uses factoring.
"I get it now," {{stu}} tells you. "But what if factoring doesn't work at the end? What other options do I have?"
"Here," you explain. "Let's change this problem just a little bit, and I'll show you." You erase the {{rhs1}} in the original problem and replace it with {{rhs2}} so that the new problem reads:
Write out and simplify a correct step-by-step solution of the new problem, explaining to {{stu}} why factoring is no longer helpful. Simplify radicals wherever possible.

outtro.p: With the new right-hand side {{rhs2}} the quadratic is no longer factorable because its discriminant is {{disc}} = {{facs}}, no longer a perfect square.
